I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Calculus!! And having the opportunity to improve even after messing up the first time.

I enjoyed mastery learning because it is very encouraging, and it gives me opportunities to improve, which has been my motivation to learn better and to try again. I also liked that we could collaborate on the Psets, it makes us feel less disconnected.

I came into this class fearing calculus and never being able to do it well, but James Barnes made it clear that no matter what, he wanted me (us students) to leave this class with the confidence of knowing how to perform these skills, and not just on one test. It took all of the anxiety away from the course, and allowed me to learn at my own pace and not feel stupid. Great class set up, I could not recommend it more.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I absolutely LOVE the mastery-based grading and learning system for this course. It makes so much sense in preparing us for life, where we will likely be able to work hard at something and gain mastery over time. It is so less stressful than other courses, where your grade is just one midterm and one final. I wish every course was graded this way!!

The only hard part is that we didn't really have enough time in the last couple of weeks to get through all of the material, making the assessments more difficult. One topic, in particular, we didn't go over at all in class. But, I think in normal years this isn't the case. COVID is weird!!
If I were to take this class again, I would want to work on/ walk through together more related problem types in class, especially those that appear in the psets.

Again, the strengths of this course are the multiple opportunities to show knowledge of the skills learned throughout the year, so that each person could focus on studies and various points and learn at their own rates. I used the tutors to my advantage to focus on anything that I was struggling with, and not just the lesson that was taught that particular week. It really helped me learn calculus much better. The only improvements I would want would be in person class (LOL).
standards grading is both good and bad.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved the pre-class videos and mastery assessment system through Canvas. It was great to get partial credit by uploading our work. Using Google JamBoard was also great, but a little hard to write without a stylist on your computer.

I am not sure if mastery learning is new because of the pandemic, but it should be more widely used! 
Jamboard personally did not help engage the class, it is difficult to "write" on, depends on what electronic devices students have access to. 
Live virtual lectures are okay, class duration was just right for me.

The attentiveness to individual students was at an all-time high, and the Professor Barnes made it so students didn't have to feel awkward at any point to ask for help, which made learning much easier! He connected us to tutors and held office hours that allowed us to talk and meet at multiple times throughout the week, often whenever was convenient for our schedules.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Great organization of the course and good foundation of calculus.
Definitely! I think other students will benefit greatly from this course.
Yes, one million times over. Do not be afraid of calculus like I was, it is set up so that you can LEARN!! This was a refreshing change from many other courses

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Pre-recorded short explanation videos to watch before class
Pre-Class videos from James, and then live small class with Pratyush.

Besides two live virtual lectures every Tuesday and Thursday, we had Canvas pre-class mini lectures and assignments, weekly problem sets, weekly HAM (Homework for Assessing Mastery), and weekly quizzes.
I had a peer tutor and separate tutor in this course, as well as the lecture by Pratyush, who was phenomenal.
